acts.title: Act 1 – Invisible Lines
acts.summary: Tension builds around unspoken expectations and small boundary slips.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
In this Act, you’ll move through a typical “small” conflict that reveals big unspoken expectations.

You’ll practice noticing when you’re being pulled into a parent role versus a supportive step-parent role, and how to name that without attacking anyone.

Meters will shift more around trust and tension here, while childStress stays relatively low but present.

acts.title: Act 2 – The Loyalty Tug-of-War
acts.summary: The child is caught in the middle; you decide how to respond.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
In Act 2, the focus moves directly to the child’s inner world.

You’ll see how small comments from adults can turn into loyalty tests in the child’s mind.

Here, childStress becomes more sensitive to your choices, while trust and tension move in subtler ways.

acts.title: Act 3 – Building a Team
acts.summary: You work toward a clearer, more stable two-home plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Act 3 invites all three adults into the frame.

You’ll experiment with language that treats everyone as part of the same extended team, even if there are old hurts.

The focus is on small, realistic agreements rather than a perfect resolution. Meters can all move here, but the emphasis is on long-term stability for the child.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Friday evening. You’re in the hallway, one shoe off, one shoe on. Your partner’s child is standing by the door, backpack on, waiting for the co-parent to arrive.

You hear your partner say from the living room, “Put that back in your room, they don’t like toys in the hallway.”

The child hesitates and glances at you, like you’re the judge of what’s allowed. You can feel the child quietly reading the room, trying to work out whose rules really count and who gets to say “we” about this home.

choices.label: Reassure the child and gently clarify the rule.
choices.text: Reassure the child and gently clarify the rule.

choices.label: Stay silent and let your partner handle it.
choices.text: Stay silent and let your partner handle it.

choices.label: Correct your partner in front of the child.
choices.text: Correct your partner in front of the child.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
A few minutes later, the co-parent arrives. The hallway feels tight: shoes, backpacks, and invisible history all in one place.

The co-parent hugs the child and throws a quick glance at you – polite, but distant.

Your partner says, “We’re trying to keep the hallway clear now, right?” and looks at you for backup. The air is full of small signals – a raised eyebrow, a half-smile, the way everyone uses the word “we” like it belongs to different teams.

choices.label: Offer a neutral, practical summary instead of taking sides.
choices.text: Offer a neutral, practical summary instead of taking sides.

choices.label: Make a small joke to diffuse the tension.
choices.text: Make a small joke to diffuse the tension.

choices.label: Point out how often the child leaves things everywhere.
choices.text: Point out how often the child leaves things everywhere.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Later that night, the house is finally quiet. The hallway is empty again, but the feeling isn’t.

Your partner sits at the kitchen table and sighs.

“I feel like you’re either too strict or too soft,” they say. “I never know what to expect from you with the rules.” Underneath the words about rules, you can hear a softer question: are you on the same side, or are you one more person the child has to manage?

choices.label: Acknowledge the confusion and ask for one small area to define together.
choices.text: Acknowledge the confusion and ask for one small area to define together.

choices.label: Defend your intentions and explain why you reacted the way you did.
choices.text: Defend your intentions and explain why you reacted the way you did.

choices.label: Point out all the times you felt undermined as a step-parent.
choices.text: Point out all the times you felt undermined as a step-parent.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
By the end of the conversation, it’s clear: nobody has ever sat down to say out loud what your role as a step-parent is supposed to be.

The hallway incident wasn’t really about shoes. It was about who gets to say “we” when it comes to the child.

Act 1 closes with a gentle realization: if the three adults don’t name the boundaries, the child will keep guessing where they are. The hallway was just the stage; the real story is about who is allowed inside the circle when someone says “we” to this child.

choices.label: Move into Act 2 – focusing on the child’s loyalty tug-of-war.
choices.text: Move into Act 2 – focusing on the child’s loyalty tug-of-war.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
A few weeks later, it’s Sunday evening. The child is back from the co-parent’s home and seems unusually quiet.

They hover near you while you cook, then blurt out:

“At Mom’s house I don’t have to ask about snacks. Here I have to ask *you* and *them*.” You notice how carefully they compare houses, like they’re trying to solve a loyalty puzzle with no wrong answer.

choices.label: Validate the child’s feelings and thank them for telling you.
choices.text: Validate the child’s feelings and thank them for telling you.

choices.label: Explain the rule differences like a teacher, focusing on structure.
choices.text: Explain the rule differences like a teacher, focusing on structure.

choices.label: Remind them that "every house has different rules" and change the subject.
choices.text: Remind them that "every house has different rules" and change the subject.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Later, after the child goes to play, your partner comes in from a call with the co-parent.

Their voice is tight. “They said you’re confusing the kid. That you’re acting like a second parent instead of a support.”

The phrase “acting like a second parent” lands like a stone in your stomach. The comment doesn’t just land on you; it ripples through the whole system, especially for a child who is already scanning every adult for safety.

choices.label: Name how that comment hits you, without attacking anyone.
choices.text: Name how that comment hits you, without attacking anyone.

choices.label: Ask your partner what *they* think, before reacting to the co-parent.
choices.text: Ask your partner what *they* think, before reacting to the co-parent.

choices.label: Suggest limiting your involvement to avoid drama.
choices.text: Suggest limiting your involvement to avoid drama.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
As the evening goes on, the “Who am I allowed to be?” question keeps floating between you and your partner.

Is your role more like a coach, a bonus parent, a housemate, an aunt/uncle?

You both realize nobody has ever said this out loud with the co-parent present, and the child has been left to interpret the silence. In the silence between sentences, you can almost hear the child’s inner voice asking, “Who am I allowed to trust without making someone else sad?”

choices.label: Propose a three-adult conversation focused on the child’s sense of safety.
choices.text: Propose a three-adult conversation focused on the child’s sense of safety.

choices.label: Ask to at least define some language you and your partner will use consistently.
choices.text: Ask to at least define some language you and your partner will use consistently.

choices.label: Decide to wait and “see how things evolve” without any plan.
choices.text: Decide to wait and “see how things evolve” without any plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Act 2 closes not with a “win”, but with a clearer map:

• The child is being loyal to *all* of you.
• Each home has different rules and different emotional climates.
• Your role as step-parent is real, but unnamed roles create extra stress.

You and your partner agree: whatever happens next needs to be less about who is right, and more about what will make life predictable for the child. Naming roles out loud is one way of telling the child they don’t have to guess the rules by reading everyone’s mood.

choices.label: Move into Act 3 – drafting a more stable “two-home” plan.
choices.text: Move into Act 3 – drafting a more stable “two-home” plan.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
You’re all at a neutral place – a café near the park. You, your partner, and the co-parent.

The child is within sight on the playground, laughing with other kids. For once, all three adults are in the same frame.

You take a breath. This could become just another round of blame. Or something else. From the playground, the child keeps glancing over as if to check whether the adults are one big storm or something closer to a patchy sky.

choices.label: Open with appreciation for what each adult is trying to do.
choices.text: Open with appreciation for what each adult is trying to do.

choices.label: Start by naming the child’s stress and your wish to reduce it.
choices.text: Start by naming the child’s stress and your wish to reduce it.

choices.label: Lead with specific complaints about past conflicts.
choices.text: Lead with specific complaints about past conflicts.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
Slowly, the conversation turns toward practical questions:

• Who explains rule differences to the child?
• How will you talk about your role when new partners enter the picture?
• What words do you *all* feel comfortable with for “step-parent”?

It’s not perfectly smooth. There are eye rolls, pauses, and some hard swallows. But it’s happening. It’s awkward and imperfect, but there is a shift from “Who is right?” to “How do we share this small word ‘we’ without squeezing the child?”

choices.label: Suggest writing down 3 shared principles to test for a month.
choices.text: Suggest writing down 3 shared principles to test for a month.

choices.label: Ask for a commitment to check in again after a few weeks.
choices.text: Ask for a commitment to check in again after a few weeks.

choices.label: Insist on resolving *everything* in this one conversation.
choices.text: Insist on resolving *everything* in this one conversation.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
By the end of the meeting, you haven’t redesigned the whole family system. But something is different:

There are a few written agreements. A plan to talk again. And a shared sentence you all agree to use when the child asks about rules or loyalty.

It sounds something like:
“You don’t have to choose between us. All of us are trying to keep you safe, even if our houses work a little differently.” For the child, these agreements aren’t theory; they are the difference between feeling like a problem and feeling like they belong to more than one safe “we.”

choices.label: Close the scenario with a brief reflection on your preferred next step.
choices.text: Close the scenario with a brief reflection on your preferred next step.

nodes.speaker: Narrator
nodes.text:
This scenario doesn’t end with a perfect blend of families.

Instead, it ends with something more realistic and more powerful:

• clearer language for your role,
• a few shared principles between the adults,
• and a slightly lighter load on the child’s shoulders.

You can replay the scenario making different choices to explore how trust, tension, and child stress shift over time. In a blended family, the child’s nervous system is often the first place conflict shows up and the last place it leaves; every small, clear “we” you build together lightens that load a little.
